title: 109_hr1196
content: SECTION 1. FINDINGS. Congress finds the need for adequate infrastructure and policies under the Department of Homeland Security to protect against potential terrorists entering the US via the Southwest Border. Al Qaeda leaders believe operatives can enter through Mexico illegally, which is more advantageous for security reasons. Border patrol records show a significant increase in non-Mexican individuals, including those from countries of interest, crossing the border. The U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement Office of Detention and Removal lacks bed space to detain all illegal immigrants from special interest countries, leading to their release on personal recognizance. Up to 90 percent of these immigrants do not appear for their immigration hearings. The Department of Homeland Security needs more personnel, security clearances, and equipment at the borders to screen and detain immigrants effectively. The Secretary of Homeland Security should provide ongoing training for inspectors and support staff to utilize new technologies. The Department of Homeland Security needs ongoing training for staff to utilize new technologies and ensure proficiency levels to protect the borders of the United States. SEC. 2. Improvement in security clearance process along the United States-Mexico border and increase in detention beds. The Secretary of Homeland Security is tasked with implementing policies to ensure personnel along the US-Mexico border have necessary security clearances for screening immigrants. This includes accessing databases like IDENT and IAFIS. Additionally, interagency agreements and information technology infrastructure will be developed for border agents. Information sharing programs with countries of interest will also be explored for screening immigrants entering the US borders. The Secretary of Homeland Security must increase detention beds to hold all immigrants caught by U.S. Customs and Border Protection. Congress believes the Office of Detention and Removal Operation should be under the control of the Commissioner of U.S. Customs and Border Protection. The Secretary of Homeland Security must increase detention beds to hold all immigrants caught by U.S. Customs and Border Protection. Congress believes the Office of Detention and Removal Operation should be under the control of the Commissioner of U.S. Customs and Border Protection. SEC. 3. STUDY OF PERSONNEL LEVELS. The Secretary of Homeland Security is required to contract with an independent entity to conduct a study on determining the necessary personnel levels at U.S. ports of entry and border patrol sectors. The study will consider the overall mission of U.S. Customs and Border Protection, threat information, the impact of new security programs, policies, and technologies, and staff cross-training. A report on the study must be submitted to congressional committees within 1 year of the enactment of the Act. The Secretary of Homeland Security is required to contract with an independent entity to conduct a study on determining necessary personnel levels at U.S. ports of entry and border patrol sectors. A report on the study must be submitted to congressional committees within 1 year. SEC. 4. ONGOING TRAINING OF BORDER SECURITY PERSONNEL. The Secretary of Homeland Security will provide continuous training for border security personnel to use new technologies and maintain acceptable proficiency levels. SEC. 5. PROMPT AND PROPER ENFORCEMENT. SEC. 5. PROMPT AND PROPER ENFORCEMENT. Congress acknowledges the critical role of prosecutors and immigration judges in enforcing immigration laws, highlighting the need for more personnel. Appropriations are authorized for staff increases in judicial and prosecutorial offices. SEC. 6. REPORT ON DETENTION AND REMOVAL OPERATIONS. The Secretary of Homeland Security must report to Congress on detention and removal operations, detailing additional space and resources needed to detain potential homeland security threats. The report should cover alternatives to detention and problematic removal countries. SEC. 7. COMPREHENSIVE BORDER SECURITY STRATEGY. The Secretary of Homeland Security, in consultation with other Federal agencies, must submit a unified strategy to secure US land borders to congressional committees within 6 months of this Act. The strategy should include actions taken to implement it.
